elements.title: Does the study evaluate a new therapeutic intervention (i.e. stage 3/4 study)?

options.text: Yes, an incremental development, modification or translation of an existing intervention
Yes, a substantial or new development

elements.tip_external:
Only award points for evaluations of therapeutic interventions, not for newly developed measurements and alike.
  • Choose “Yes, an incremental development“ if the intervention has already been evaluated before and only a small change, translation or addition is being evaluated.
  • Choose “Yes, a substantial or new development” if a new intervention or major changes are being evaluated.
Look at the references to understand whether the intervention has been evaluated before.

options.text: No, the manual is not published or only accessible upon reasonable request
Yes, the manual is published with a restrictive/commercial license
Yes, the manual is published under an open license (e.g., CC-BY)

elements.title: ⤷ DOI or URL of the manual
elements.info: You can add multiple DOIs or URLs, separated by a semicolon (;)

elements.title: Was this study a randomized controlled trial (RCT)?
elements.info:
A randomized controlled trial (RCT) is a research design that aims to evaluate the causal effects of an intervention by randomly assigning participants to either an intervention group or a control group. Any research design that follows these principles counts as an RCT within RESQUE (even if the study does not call itself like that).
While RCTs often include additional safeguards such as allocation concealment, blinding of participants and personnel, and adherence to the intention-to-treat principle, these are not necessary in RESQUE.
elements.tip_external: Many RCTs in teh clinical context mention explicitly, often even in the title, that they are RCTs. The challenge is to identify experimental designs that are in fact RCTs without explicitly calling themselves as such. RCTs aim at identifying causal effects. If the main outcome is about a prediction, this is a good indicator that probably no RCT was done.

elements.title: Was the primary outcome from the preregistration reported as the main finding in the paper?
elements.tip_external: To answer this question, check whether the primary outcome named in the preregistration is also the main result discussed in the article—usually emphasized in the abstract, results, and conclusion. If the preregistered primary outcome is not reported or a different one is prioritized in the paper, answer “No.” If no primary outcome was preregistered, select “Not applicable” and explain why.

elements.title: ⤷ Provide the name of the primary outcome
Which criteria apply to this RCT?

options.text: Assessments were conducted by independent assessors
Control group was specifically defined (not just TAU but explicit statement of the performed interventions)
Group assignment was truly random (e.g. assignment through random numbers generator, not by time of inclusion)
Adherence of therapists was operationalized, controlled and reported

elements.info:
“Truly random”: When evaluating whether the randomization in an RCT was truly random, look for a clear and explicit description of how the random sequence was generated. Acceptable methods include:
  • the use of computer-generated random numbers,
  • random number tables,
  • or centralized randomization procedures
Simply stating that participants were “randomly assigned” is not sufficient unless the method used to generate the sequence is also described. If the randomization is described as “manual,” it is crucial to determine whether this manual method involves a pre-prepared randomization list.
If instead participants were allocated by alternation, admission date, judgment of the researcher, or any other predictable or subjective method, the study does not meet the criterion of true randomization. See https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4350496/.

elements.title: ⤷ Provide the type of the randomization method
Were patient representatives (experts by experience) included at any stage of the research process for this study?
elements.info:
This includes but is not limited to: involvement of patients in study design, dissemination or translation of results. Exemplary keywords in the text are:
  • patient (/family/caretaker) perspective
  • patient and public involvement (PPI)
  • patient partner
  • patient(/family/caretaker) insights
The Information could also be stated in the acknowledgements. Two examples from publications that included patients:

  • 'We enhanced the usability of our findings by engaging key stakeholders (i.e. clinicians, parents and researchers) as part of our integrated knowledge translation activities […]. Their guidance ensured that the review findings were both clinically meaningful and family-centred.” (McPherson et al., 2017)'
  • 'Patient discussion groups were used as a means of involving patients in setting the research question and for determining the outcome measures' (Wilson et al., 2019)
When to select what?
  • Select “Yes” if such involvement is documented at any stage of the research process.
  • Select “No” if no patient representatives were involved or if their involvement is not described.
  • Select “Not applicable” only if the study is conducted in a context where meaningful or feasible involvement of patient representatives is not possible (e.g., purely methodological simulations without connection to a specific patient population).

elements.title: Does the study publish results that overall disconfirm or even contradict the original hypotheses?

options.text: Not applicable (e.g., the study was purely explorative) [provide explanation]

elements.info: Think counterfactually: Could the study in theory have provided a result that leads to a disconfirmation? If yes (but it did not disconfirm any prior hypothesis), then you choose “No” (it did not contradict or disconfirm). Most qualitative studies fall into the “not applicable” category, as they rarely test a priori hypotheses.

elements.title: ⤷ Describe why the publication of this null result was important.
